title: Piston - Assembly

body.body: Connecting rods may be fitted either way around. However, make sure all three are fitted the same way.
Lubricate the piston, small end and gudgeon pin with a 50/50 solution of engine oil and molybdenum disulphide grease.
Failure to use new gudgeon pin circlips could allow the pin to detach from the piston. This could seize the engine, resulting in loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Fit a new circlip to one side of the gudgeon pin making sure the circlip is correctly fitted in the groove.
Align the small end in the connecting rod with the gudgeon pin hole in the piston.
If the original pistons are being refitted, make sure they are fitted in their original connecting rods.
If a circlip is dropped into the crankcase, it must be recovered before the crankshaft is rotated. Failure to do so will result in serious engine damage.
Insert the gudgeon pin into the piston and push it fully into position.
Secure the gudgeon pin in position with the remaining new circlip. Make sure the circlip is correctly located in the piston groove.
Do not allow the pistons to fall against the crankcase when turning the engine. Piston and/or crankcase damage could occur if the pistons are not supported while turning the engine.
Position the piston ring end gaps as follows (piston viewed from above, triangular mark facing forwards).
The top compression ring gap should be in the 12 o'clock position.
The second compression ring gap should be in the 6 o'clock position.
The first oil control ring gap should be in the 12 o'clock position.
The second oil control ring gap should be in the 6 o'clock position.
The oil control ring expander gap should be in the 7 o'clock position.
